What did early Canadian farmers eat?  
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. A.D. Hunter  
Address: 207 33rd St West, Saskatoon, Sask.  
Birthplace: Manitoba, Man.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1911  
Where did you set up housekeeping? Collingwood, Sask.  
How far was it to your nearest store? 40 miles  
How often could a visit be made to the store? Average once in two weeks  
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Staple goods, no luxuries

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?  
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50  
How much did you use Graham flour? 50 lbs  
Whole wheat flour? 50 lbs  
Was flour milled locally? Yes  
How far away? 40 miles  
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 60 cents  
What other grain products did you use?  
Cornmeal? Yes  
Whole wheat? No  
Farina? No  
Other? Bran and shorts  
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes, sometimes  
How did you grind it? Meal grinder
1. INTER-COUNTY TRAVELING

What year did you start traveling? 1911
Where did you go? To Montana County
How far was it? 35 miles
How many people did you travel with? 3
How long did you stay there? 4 weeks
How often could you visit? Every two weeks
What goods did you usually buy in those counties? Staple goods

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of flour did you use in the early years?
What was the usual price per pound of flour? $2.50
How much did you pay per bushel? $5.00
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty-pound bag of flour? $1.00
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? Yes
Other? No

3. CLOTHING

What year did you start buying clothes? 1911
Where did you go? To Montana County
How far was it? 35 miles
How many people did you travel with? 3
How long did you stay there? 4 weeks
How often could you visit? Every two weeks
What goods did you usually buy in those counties? Staple goods

4. HOUSEHOLD ITEMS

What year did you start buying household items? 1911
Where did you go? To Montana County
How far was it? 35 miles
How many people did you travel with? 3
How long did you stay there? 4 weeks
How often could you visit? Every two weeks
What goods did you usually buy in those counties? Staple goods
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 10 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $4.50 in 1911.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Meyer.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs.

At what price? about 6 cents.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

Milked cows.

Butter? Made it.

Eggs? Handlaid.

What was the price of butter? 15¢ average.

Of eggs? 5¢ each.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

How? Cans, salt, or waterglass.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Sweet milk with rennet.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Butchered.

Pork and beef.

How did you get fresh meat?

How often did you get fresh meat? Winter time.

How did you preserve meat? Dry salt.

Some used brine.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? No.

What kinds?

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not very much.

We used to get on the frozen fish.

Has the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds? Frozen, Jack fish, white fish, turibos.

6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbon. At what price? $.5 cents.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) Beans.

Price? $.6 cents. What other beverages were used?

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? $2.00/bushel. Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes.

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1913. Cabbage 1914. Carrots 1914. Onions 1914.

Turnips 1914. Beets 1914.

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 10 lbs.

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? Box.

What weight? 40 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Box or brick.

What was the price of prunes? $.85.

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)? Yes.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? Peas? Yes. Corn? No. Beans? No. Saskatoons? No.

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1915.

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1930.

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1930.

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning.

To what extent? Average family. 25% mixed.

Did you make your own vinegar? Yes.

### 12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout)  
**mostly well water**

How far was this water from your home?  
**in the yard**

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)  
**Pail barrel**

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

**Everyone has got water curtains fresh daily from the well for drinking & cooking.**

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made it.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ash?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Maguire Royal

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood & Buffalo chips.

Where did you get your fuel? Coal in winter.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

There is lots of oil and Propane gas used now where the power lines not gone thru.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? The Olneys.

What year was it purchased? 1911. Price? $14.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

Enamel, Tin.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? Always.

Aluminum? 1920.

16. **Packaging and Containers**

   Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

   Packaging started in the 30's, and cellophane about 10 years later.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   **Breakfast:** Porridge. Coffee & milk. Eggs sometimes bread, syrup or jam - butter, cream.

   **Dinner:** Meat, potatoes, and veg. Bread, butter and milk pudding.

   **Supper:** Meat & eggs, fried potatoes, preserved fruit, bread & butter. 4 children from 2 to 10.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? 1913. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   Family & in-laws, and some neighbors.

   Mrs. Mrs. E. Lafferty, elderly couple.

   Mrs. Mrs. D. Sherry, 19 years.

   Mrs. Mrs. A. Robertson, + family, 25 to 28 years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   Absolutely not.
Packaging started in Nov. 30, 8, and ended Oct. 6, 1945.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner, & supper) for the enlist-
ment you can remember. Give the year and list the names of the family
with their ages at the time. State the approximate number of children
or spouses.

Breakfast. Porridge. Coffee & milk. Egg & toast.
Bread, syrup or jam. Butter, cream. Bread, butter,
biscuits, potatoes, and sugar.

Dinner. Meat, potatoes, and milk pudding. Pressed
and milk puddings. Pressed potatoes. Pressed
fruit bread & butter. 4 children from 3 to 10.

Supper. Meal or eggs. Pressed potatoes. Pressed
fruit bread & butter. 4 children from 3 to 10.

12. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?
Give the names of the people present and give their
addresses, if any.

1943. Mrs. E. Loffman. Absolutely unable.

Mrs. Miss A. Robertson. Family. 25 to 18 years.

Mrs. Miss A. Robertson. Family. 25 to 18 years.

19. Were you ever reduced to about starvation level living on one or two
locally produced foods? Give details.

Absolutely not.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We had to prepare everything we ate in the early years. Now you can buy it all ready.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

The last 15 years, we still prepare a lot of our own.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

We really had no trouble to get anything we needed. We had 240 miles to go to town. Until we got there, we could get almost everything. Sugar during the first World War was hard to get, but they allowed us to get it in bigger quantities as we were so far from town.
